questions.text: 1. A child presents with trigeminal neuralgia associated with painful vesicular lesions around the mouth. On inoculation of the cell culture, multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions were seen. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child complaining of painful vesicular lesions around the mouth, with histopathology showing multinucleated giant cells, suggests the most probable diagnosis to be oral herpes caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV).

Herpes infection can be caused by the HSV-1 and HSV-2 viruses. HSV-1 causes orofacial lesions, i.e. herpes labialis, while HSV-2 mainly causes genital herpes which is characterised by vesiculoulcerative lesions of the penis of the male or the cervix, vulva, vagina, and perineum of the female. Genital herpes is often accompanied by symptoms like fever, headache, malaise, and myalgia, pain, itching, dysuria, vaginal and urethral discharge, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis of herpes simplex virus:

* Most sensitive test- HSV DNA- PCR (can differentiate between HSV 1 and 2)

* Virus isolation 

* Histopathology showing multinucleated giant cells

* Microscopy - Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, shows Tzanck cells. These are multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass chromatin. 

The following image shows the histology of HSV inclusion bodies.



The image given below shows Tzanck cells.

questions.text: 2. A patient presents with an asymptomatic macular lesion since childhood. Diascopy was inconclusive and Wood lamp examination showed white accentuation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is nevus depigmentosus.

This condition presents as a stable, congenital or early childhood hypopigmented macule. On Wood’s lamp examination, the lesion shows white accentuation. The lesion remains non-progressive and asymptomatic throughout life, which fits the case scenario. 

Nevus depigmentosus is a stable, well-circumscribed hypopigmented patch that is present at birth and may become more noticeable during the first year as the surrounding skin pigmentation develops. There is usually a single oval or rectangular lesion, but the presence of three or more nevus depigmentosus or hypomelanotic patches in a newborn should raise suspicion for possible tuberous sclerosis complex. It is a congenital nonprogressive hypopigmented macule or patch that is stable in its relative size and distribution throughout life. 

Nevus depigmentosus can be diagnosed using the following criteria:

* Leukoderma present at birth or of early onset

* No alteration in the distribution of leukoderma throughout life

* No alteration in texture or change in sensation in the affected area

* Absence of hyperpigmented border.

Diascopy test is negative in nevus depigmentosus but positive in nevus anemicus. Wood's lamp examination demonstrates an off-white color. Histopathologic examination shows normal to decreased number of melanocytes with S-100 stain. Mostly it does not require any treatment as it is non-progressive and adequate counseling is sufficient.

Other options:

Option A: Nevus anemicus are pale macules or patches most often on the trunk. They can be distinguished from other differentials because of their response to firm stroking. Stroking evokes an erythematous line and flare in normal surrounding skin, but the skin of a nevus anemicus does not redden.

They can also be diagnosed by diascopy, in which pressure of the skin with a glass slide will obscure the borders of a nevus anemicus. In this case, diascopy was inconclusive, making nevus anemicus less likely. The image below shows nevus anemicus:



Option B: Vitiligo is an acquired condition resulting from the progressive loss of melanocytes.It is characterised by milky‐white, sharply demarcated macules. Under Wood’s lamp, vitiligo lesions appear chalky white due to the complete absence of melanin. Since the lesion here has been stable since childhood and not progressive, vitiligo is ruled out.



Option D: Indeterminate leprosy presents as hypopigmented macules with reduced sensation and poorly defined margins. The case mentions an asymptomatic lesion with no sensory loss, making indeterminate leprosy unlikely.

questions.text: 3. A 68-year-old farm labourer presented with a swelling over the right foot for 2 years, which was initially asymptomatic but now has serous discharge and occasional black granules. KOH mount of the discharge will reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
KOH mount of the discharge is most likely to show septate hyphae of 4 to 5 microns. 

A chronic foot swelling with draining sinuses with black granules is classic for eumycetoma, mainly caused by Madurella mycetomatis. On KOH mount, the crushed black grains typically show slender, septate hyphae 4–5 microns in diameter.

Mycetoma is a localized chronic infection caused by various species of fungi (eumycetoma) and aerobic actinomycetes (actinomycetoma). The causal organisms produce a chronic inflammatory reaction leading to focal neutrophil abscess formation, with scattered giant cells and fibrosis. Grains in the form of white, yellow, red or black granules are found in the centre of the inflammatory response, and may be discharged in pus through multiple sinuses onto the skin surface.

A tentative diagnosis can be made on the basis of grain colour, texture and direct microscopic appearance. Pus should be examined under the microscope for the presence of grains, which may then be processed for histology or examined directly in potassium hydroxide.

If the infection is eumycotic, when crushed under the cover slip, the grains will be seen to consist of masses of fungal mycelium with septate hyphae of 4 to 5 microns. The final identification of the infecting fungus requires the isolation of the causal agent in culture or by molecular diagnostic techniques. 

Other options:

Option A: Arthrospores are seen in dermatophytes (tinea infections).

Option B: Budding yeast with pseudohyphae is typical of Candida infections.

Option C: Hyphae with flower-like conidia describe Sporothrix schenckii (sporotrichosis).

questions.text: 4. An 8 year old girl presented with follicular hyperkeratotic papules over the elbow, knees and buttocks. She has dry skin and lusterless hair. Which of the following is the next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ocular examination is the next step in evaluation. 

This child’s presentation with follicular hyperkeratotic papules over extensor surfaces, dry skin, and lusterless hair is characteristic of phrynoderma, which is a manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency. The next important step in evaluation is to assess for ocular involvement (to look for conjunctival xerosis, Bitot’s spots, keratomalacia), since Vitamin A deficiency can lead to visual impairment if not detected early.

The earliest sign of vitamin A deficiency is defective dark adaptation and night blindness (nyctalopia), followed by xerophthalmia. Aberrant keratinization in the oral and nasal mucosa may result in hyposmia and hypogeusia. Patients also often complain of generalized xerosis.

Ocular complications range from night blindness, corneal xerosis and Bitot spots (white keratinized lesions) to corneal ulceration, keratomalacia, corneal perforation, iris prolapse and blindness. The most significant complication of severe vitamin A deficiency is blindness.

Cutaneous findings include xerosis and scaling, dermomalacia and phrynoderma. Phrynoderma is characterized by keratotic follicular papules involving the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms, and can spread to the extensor extremities, shoulders, posterior neck, back, buttocks and abdomen.

Treatment is done by administering 50,000–2,00,000 IU of daily vitamin A supplementation until clinical signs and symptoms resolve and serum retinol levels normalize. 

The image below shows a Bitot's spot seen on the surface of the conjunctiva:



Other options:

Option A: Vitamin D deficiency causes rickets/osteomalacia, not follicular keratotic papules.

Option B: Deep tendon reflex is relevant for neurological causes (e.g., B12 deficiency), not for keratotic papules.

Option C: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia and neurological signs, not dry skin with keratotic papules.

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text:
5. A 48-year-old male presented with an asymptomatic lesion on the right cheek with central atrophy, which had been slowly progressive over the last 2 years. CXR reveals apical calcification. How will you confirm the diagnosis?

CXR: Chest X-Ray

PCR: Polymerase Chain Reaction
questions.solution:
PCR is used to confirm the diagnosis.

The above clinical scenario of a slow, progressive, painless plaque over the cheek and side of the neck and the characteristic reddish-brown nodules, plaques, and ulcers with variable scarring and a serpiginous edge are suggestive of lupus vulgaris and chest X-ray showing apical calcification suggests healed pulmonary tuberculosis. Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in previously sensitised individuals, and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

Skin biopsy is usually helpful, but since the quantity of bacilli encountered in cutaneous lesions is small, stains for acid-fast bacilli are usually negative. A chest X-ray will help to analyse the pulmonary involvement.

Lupus vulgaris originates from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, typically in a bone, joint, or lymph node, or maybe from the hematogenous and lymphatic spread. It can also occur over a primary site of inoculation, such as the site of scrofuloderma scar, BCG vaccine, and after a tattoo. 

It presents as a slowly enlarging plaque with an elevated border and central atrophy. The edges of the lesion are often serpiginous in shape and heal with scarring. In India, the buttocks and trunk are more frequently involved. In Europe, most of the lesions are present on the head, neck, and face. The diascopy of lesions reveals diagnostic apple jelly nodules.

Polymerase chain reaction has been successfully used to confirm the diagnosis. Skin biopsy is usually helpful, but since the quantity of bacilli encountered in cutaneous lesions is small, stains for acid-fast bacilli are usually negative and hence, culture may be more helpful.  Standard multidrug therapy for tuberculosis is used for the treatment. Isoniazid monotherapy is not given anymore due to the emergence of isoniazid-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains.

The image given below shows lupus vulgaris in the axilla:



Other options:

Option A: Probe test is generally used to detect bone involvement in osteomyelitis, not in lupus vulgaris. 

Option C: Slit smear is used for detecting Mycobacterium leprae in leprosy, and is usually negative in cutaneous tuberculosis. 

Option D: Mantoux test is often positive in tuberculosis, but cannot confirm active disease, as it may also be positive in healthy exposed individuals.

questions.text: 6. A 45-year-old male presents with a complaint of pruritic rash over the elbows, knees and buttocks. He recently visited the gastroenterology OPD and was found to be sensitive to gluten. Skin biopsy showed IgA immunofluorescence. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of intensely itchy lesions on the extensor aspect of both elbows and knees with direct immunofluorescence (DIF) showing focal granular deposits along the basement membrane is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis. 

Dermatitis herpetiformis, also known as Duhring’s disease is an auto-immune disease associated with HLA DQ-2 and HLA DQ-8. The antibodies target epidermal transglutaminase-3, resulting in the collection of neutrophils at the dermal papilla. This condition is closely associated with Celiac disease (Gluten-sensitive enteropathy). 

The clinical manifestations include grouped vesicles and papules. These lesions are commonly located over the extensor aspects of knees, elbows, buttocks, back, and scalp with symmetrical distribution and are associated with intense pruritus. 

The characteristic histopathology finding is subepidermal blisters with papillary tip microabscesses containing neutrophils, which is shown in the image below:



A gluten-free diet is the mainstay of treatment, but it takes months to years to show clinical improvement. Hence, dapsone is used for short-term management in these patients.

questions.text: 7. A female presented with patches in the oral cavity with complaints of burning sensation after taking a drug for 6 months. Symptoms worsened on eating spicy food. Which drug is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Beta blocker is most likely to cause this condition. 

The image shows reticular white patches with erosions in the oral cavity, causing a burning sensation, especially with spicy food. The findings are characteristic of oral lichen planus, and among drugs that can trigger this condition, the most commonly associated drug is a beta blocker.

Lichenoid drug eruption is a type of adverse reaction to certain medications that causes skin or oral lesions resembling lichen planus. The drugs most commonly implicated in lichenoid drug eruptions include antimalarials, gold, NSAIDs, penicillamine, thiazide diuretics, mercury amalgam, ACE inhibitors, beta blockers, lithium, methyldopa, and other sulfonylureas. Out of the given options, beta blockers are considered one of the most potent generators for the drug-induced forms of lichen planus, compared to lithium (Option B). 

Lichen planus-like drug reactions usually develop months or even years after starting the medication. They manifest as shiny purple papules or plaques, sometimes with the characteristic Wickham’s striae (thin white lines on their surface), and can involve mucous membranes. Diagnosis relies on skin biopsy, which typically shows hyperkeratosis, hypergranulosis, saw-tooth acanthosis, and a band-like infiltrate in the upper dermis. Features that suggest a drug-related cause include necrotic keratinocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils.

Treatment centers on discontinuing the offending drug, which is crucial for resolution. Most cases improve with topical corticosteroids, while oral corticosteroids may be necessary for extensive or severe eruptions. Symptoms generally resolve within weeks to months after stopping the drug. 

Other options:

Option C: Fluconazole is an antifungal, used to treat oral candidiasis and other fungal infections. It does not typically cause lichenoid drug eruption

Option D: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone and can cause tendon ruptures, joint pain, gastrointestinal upset, and neurological side effects. Oral lichenoid lesions are not a well-known adverse effect.
